column1: Tar-Minastir was the grandson of King [[Tar-Súrion]]. Before becoming King he used the name Minastir. He succeeded his aunt, Queen [[Tar-Telperiën]]. His name meant "Tower Watcher", which he acquired after building a tall tower upon the hill of [[Oromet]], near [[Andúnië]], in order to gaze westwards.<ref name="Kings">{{UT
During his time, in [[Middle-earth]], [[Sauron]] invaded [[Eriador]] from [[Calenardhon]] in {{SA
column2: 1695}} and the realms of [[Eregion]] fell.  He then advanced to [[Lindon]] and besieged [[Rivendell]]. In {{SA
column4: n}} Minastir (who envied the [[Eldar]], but nonetheless he loved them<ref name=app>{{App
column5: Numenor}}</ref>) sent a navy under the command of [[Ciryatur]] to save Lindon. Ciryatur's forces stopped Sauron's army in the clash known as [[Battle of the Gwathló]] and reinforcements from Lindon and [[Tharbad]] helped defeat the enemy. Sauron retreated back to [[Mordor]].<ref name="Galad">{{UT

column1: Starting around the 1800s, the Númenóreans began establishing permanent settlements in [[Middle-earth]], including the [[Umbar

Tar-Minastir abdicated in 1869 and was succeeded by his son, [[Tar-Ciryatan]].<ref name="Kings"/> Tar-Minastir was one of the last "good" Kings of the realm, as his successors started becoming greedy.<ref name=app/>
In ''The Tale of Years'' it is stated that Tar-Minastir sent a great navy from Númenor to Lindon in {{SA
column2: 1700}}.<ref name="SA"/>  This event and date are restated in ''The History of Galadriel and Celeborn'', mentioning Tar-Minastir again.<ref name="Galad"/>  Yet in ''The Line of Elros'' Tar-Telperiën is said to have lived to {{SA
column3: 1731}} and not have given up the Sceptre until that time, which would mean she was the ruler of Númenor when the great navy was sent.  [[Christopher Tolkien]] could not account for this discrepancy.<ref>{{UT
